Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned quite a bit about how the planet works through the lens of natural disasters. Yes, I can now tell you how earthquakes happen, but the underlying mechanics (plate tectonics etc.) are fascinating, as well. Great refresher on high school algebra if you've forgotten, too.
This class is a general overview of natural disasters and their sources of energy.
I learned how to approach a Yale course in this class.
A lot of geological information about the earth and its essence. Specifically not just case studies about natural disasters but why they occur.
basic info about science
HS level science class about common geological and meteorological phenomenon

This class is what you make of it. It's not a joke as people make it out to be and you do have the potential to learn if you chose to. The averages on our midterms were a B- and B so its by no means a guaranteed A.  Our weekly P-sets took a surprising amount of time and office hours were often filled since the material was significantly harder than what we were doing in lectures. In the end, if you need a science credit its a relatively painless way to get it. Otherwise, I'm not sure what you're doing in this class.
learned some about natural disasters
learned so much about the various different natural disasters!

I learned a great deal about how the world operates on a very basic level. This class was useful in understanding the components that drive natural processes on Earth, and how these systems affect our lives today.

Imagine not knowing anything about how the world works and now knowing more than one thing about how the world works. While this class is called Natural Disasters, and you do learn about earthquakes, hurricanes, and asteroid impacts, you learn a lot about what allows them to exist: how the universe and solar system were formed, how the earth was formed, how plates have moved and changed the world's climate, how clouds themselves form, how plate tectonics allow life on earth, or how life on earth formed.

This class was amazing. It was so interesting to learn about the science behind everyday natural occurrences. From hurricanes and tornados to earthquakes and volcanoes, to basic thunderstorms, this class provided information of how all of these natural disasters occur.

This course provided an overview of almost all the natural disasters that are relevant and occurring in our world today. This course helped me understand why they happen and where they are most likely to happen.
I learned about the causes of natural disasters of all kinds, ranging from geological to meteorological to cosmological, and how to model geophysical processes mathematically and theoretically.

I really enjoyed taking Natural Disasters and feel as though I learned a lot. I not only learned about natural disasters, including the warning signs for natural disasters and what to do if I find myself in one, I also learned about the formation of our planet and about the greater planetary system.
I got my QR and learned more about earthquakes.

I learned the fundamentals of geologic, meteorologic, and cosmologic disasters to sum it up in one sentence. That included things like plate tectonics, the Coriolis effect, and El Nio just to name a few.
Learned the basic causes for natural disasters.

I realized how much goes on in the world around me that I was not aware of before. It's been really great to know how storms form, and all the plate tectonic activity that helps the world survive. Who knew volcanism was so important.
This class offers an insight into how the world works through the frame of natural disaste

I learned about the historical background of the universe and (more in-depth), our planet. I learned about what makes natural phenomena occur, and how humans can work to keep the population and prevent/reduce destruction from these events.
Basic knowledge of natural disasters
Basic overview of some natural phenomena/disasters
I learned about the causes and processes involved with natural disasters.

I loved this class so much, that I switched my intended major from Middle Eastern Studies & Religious Studies to Geology & Geophysics + Something in the humanities. I had originally signed up because natural disasters are a significant part of humanitarian operations, development, global warming impacts, etc. Not only did the professors include many of these real-world intersections and talk about tons of examples with every scientific concept, but I also came to enjoy the science of it all too. My intention coming into Yale was to only take two science classes and make them as easy and humanities based as possible, and now I am psyched to take not one, but two terms of physics, a term of chemistry, and more science classes down the road. In high school, I'd never taken a hard science course past freshman conceptual physics, so there was a steep learning curve for me to do the problem sets. Section was really really great, and the professors have set up tutoring drop-in sections too, which were enormously helpful. I would go to section, where the professors walked us through the problem sets and helped us learn the math and physics to set up the problems, then we did them on our own. I needed additional help to figure out some of the things I just copied, so going to the tutoring drop-in hours was really really great, so much so that every time I turned in a p-set, I understood what I was doing. I am thrilled by how much I learned in the course and how much I see things I learned in my life and just to understand.Natural disasters deeply impacted my family this fall in both Houston and San Juan; to me, it just felt a little better knowing the science behind why. I also am a huge hiker, camper, backpacker, etc, so learning about a bunch of the ideas (in particular, how thunderstorms form) was really exciting and relevant to me to see what I've learned when I'm out. Overall, the professors were really really great-they were both so friendly and helpful, and their lectures were awesome. Their enthusiasm is also contagious! Goodness, I ramble a lot.

I developed an understanding about the causes and effects of Natural Disasters, as well as the interaction between the earth and the universe. This was an incredibly exciting course with well organized and well taught interesting subject matter.
Information about the types of natural disasters and how they occur
Basic knowledge of geology, climate, and effects of astronomical bodies on the Earth.

I gained great insight into how natural disasters occur and the energy systems providing the fuel for such a disaster to occur. I also learned about the specifics of such events, which helped refine and increase my knowledge of these events.
Learned a lot about the earth and how natural disasters occur. Very practical knowledge.

I learned about the formation of the earth, the climate, the development of life, and various natural disasters. I also learned about how all of these processes are integrated and how they impact life on earth.
A better understanding of the physics behind everyday physical processes.

I learned about natural processes such as earthquakes, hurricanes, tsunami, volcanoes, floods, storms, asteroid impacts, and climate change. We learned about the scientific basis of these processes, their impacts on humans, how to prepare for disasters, and historical examples.
Applying math to how the world works. Learned a lot on how the world works in general.

Never went to class, survived 

But for real went to a total of 3 lectures
Better understanding the driving force behind natural disasters of all sorts and understanding what really occurs when we experience them.
Always had a great interest on how nature functions and this class did not disappoint in expanding my knowledge.
I learned about natural disaster that occur on earth and their causes

We learned about every type of natural disaster and how they happen (scientifically). More than that though, learning this really made you learn about the universe as a whole and earth's placement within it. It was also a nice littler refresher on some really basic physics.
Gained knowledge of a variety of earth science related topics as well as practical knowledge related to natural disasters.

I've learned the value of understanding units in solving difficult math/physics problems. I've also learned to take notes better in general and to figure out what is important/not important to understanding the core issues of what we were studying at the time.
This course improved my ability to do physics related math as well as advancing my knowledge of how natural disasters occur.
Interesting material, great professors, fair exams. Student engagement was lacking at times (probably because of the reputation as a gut) but you'll get out of it what you put into it.
Professor is strength, math is weakness. I feel like the problem sets are not necessary, as we do not go over the math in class.
The homeworks do not relate to the course material. I truly felt it was busy work. The (25%) conceptual questions were the only value in the homework.
Strengths include the teachers and interesting/relevant material but a lot of math for a non-QR credit and the problem sets were difficult to do even with attending lecture and reading the textbook.
i liked how there were two different professors who taught in different ways to make the class more engaging.
eh pretty good for what it's worth. Loved the inclass demonstrations, maybe incorporate those into fun sections.
The professors were great. Both very involved in the class and made a concerted effort to get everyone excited.
Dont know, never went to class
super interesting material and super awesome professors!!! a slightly more quantitative approach could be cool but i understand why it's not organized that way

The strengths of this course are that the discussion sections are easy to attend and understand, and that concepts needed for tests are generally explained very clearly. Also the lecture slides are all posted on Canvas, which makes studying for the tests a lot easier. The weaknesses of this class are that lectures can get a bit dry and, and the problem sets sometimes took longer than expected. These issues could possibly be improved by making lectures more engaging and making problem sets shorter or less tedious.

The class is very interesting and the problem sets were a good way to review the material. I really enjoyed Professor Long's demonstrations. Professor Burcovici and Professor Long worked very well together.

This class is amazing! I don't think it could be improved. The lecture structure is great and having the conceptual days after each disaster type was very appreciated. Also having option section that helped with psets was ideal.
The lectures were very clear and the sections offered routinely to help with homework problem sets were also very helpful. The lectures were extremely useful when studying for tests.

The strengths of this class include the professors, who are both engaging and enthusiastic, and the material itself, which is fascinating. The only weaknesses was that the problem sets often involved somewhat tedious arithmetic.

I think the material in this course was genuinely interesting. I learned a lot about the earth. 

I think the way the subject matter was presented, especially in the latter end of the course, was not always conducive to helping people without a geologic background learn this material. Oftentimes, lectures included a boatload of information, which was difficult to distill to the main points. However, going to section definitely helped me do this. 

As far as exams, I really preferred the structure of the final to those of the midterms. Yes, there were more questionsbut each question was worth fewer points.

Strength: the sections are super helpful, as are the professors and TA's! 

Always go to the section! For all problem sets!

Strengths: Lectures for Prof. Long involving more conceptual framework of causes for natural disasters. 

Weaknesses: Too quantitative for a class that is a science credit. Would have preferred problem sets that included more conceptual questions since the tests were mostly based off those.

Love that the class was taught 3 times a week--repetition helped with retention. Prof.s Berkovici and Long knew how to make the information digestible and were a delight to listen to. They were really focused on making sure that we remember the basics down the line so they didn't force us to memorize unessential details that we would forget right away--really appreciated that because I think it worked!

The strength of this course was in the engaging material. It could be improved with respect to the teaching of physics concepts, as it was too difficult for non-science majors, and too simple for science majors.

This course is often sped through material that was later discovered to be important (appearing on exams), but would harp on math problems that would have been possible to do without such extensive help, and did not contribute as much to the critical knowledge that we should have gained have from the course.
Weaknesses: A lot of superfluous material, ie names of specific volcanoes, earthquakes, etc.
I really like the in depth lectures. I found those lectures to be much more informative, interesting, and engaging than the other lectures.

The professors are great, super enthusiastic, and very helpful if you are interested in the class, (show up), and talk to them! 
The power points are fabulous, so much so that you do not even need to open your textbook. If you want to save money, you don't need it at all. I don't regret buying it though because it's really well written, very readable, and frankly, I was really interested in the topics so I'm keeping it too to finish reading it. 
If you get P. Bercovici's book, (which looks cute, but don't be fooled-it's dense), the questions on the problem set feel even more relevant. I read the book over winter break after finishing the class, and I realized that the seemingly random questions actually were so important and relevant and their answers are discussed in the book, so it was cool to know the math and concepts behind their conclusion.
The sections are great; they're really really great and super helpful. Yes, they walk you through the problem, but for me, I spent a lot of time afterwards understanding each step that I copied. If they hadn't gotten us so far in section, I would not have had the time to really understand each of the problems and some I would not have figured out at all. 
Again, both professors were amazing-I can't even stress that enough!
Strong course with clear lectures, homework help sessions, and exams. Occasionally the homework problem setups were difficult to understand, but it was easy to get help in the optional sections.
The optional sections are very helpful
Improvement of review sessions

It is interesting and applicable to immediate world events. The work assigned doesn't do a great job of teaching you the concepts. For a gut, there is some tedious math to do in this class. The psets are graded pretty strictly so I generally spent 4-5 hours a week finishing and then going over them. I'd also often have to go back through lectures to get concepts down before I could start the pset.
The sections for this course were very good and extremely productive. This was definitely a   major strength of the course.

This class was very interesting and the lectures were highly engaging. I feel as though I have a much greater understanding about how the earth works and can appreciate how disasters and normal geologic processes effect life. However, I think some of the p-sets were needlessly more difficult than they had to be. I would never have been able to work out some of the equations without going to section, which was a bit frustrating at times.

This course was very straightforward and a great course for anyone looking for an intro into G&G or for a science credit. Exam material was pretty identical to lecture topics and problem sets were sometimes challenging but office hours were very helpful.

I really enjoyed this course and learned a lot every lecture. However, some lectures were confusing/rambling, and I came out of them very uncertain about what was the information I actually needed to know vs tangents, and some topics were much more confusing in lecture than they needed to be.
It's a very captivating class. I found the material to be extremely entertaining
I thought this class was great - only thing was that the psets and the test material didnt overlap all that much which was sometimes frustrating but understandable

The subject material in itself was very interesting. The course however was awful. Lecture was pointless, as they hardly taught anything on the p sets- which was 90% math. If you couldnt attend the optional sections, you had no chance of passing. Also, it took 10 days to grade a 4 question p set, I ended up failing the first p sets because of a simple error, and I never got feedback so I made the same mistake in the second one and failed that one too. Also, the midterms have one math question on them. So its hours of p sets on things never covered in class to take midterms on things not covered in p sets. If you didnt memorize the book you were screwed.

I thought this class was structured very well! It has been taught for a while and it shows. Sometimes we had to rush through lectures but it was ok because we could review whatever was rushed through after class.

I thought this was a great course. We learned a lot, it was very interesting and well explained. Maybe the only thing I can think of is it would be interesting to learn about a bit more practical stuff about what to do in the event of natural disasters (we did talk about this briefly) as well as engineering solutions, etc.

The readings for the class can definitely be more streamlined. Instead of having to read the entire chapter, since much of the readings were not relevant to the tests or what we discussed in lectures, the readings can be specified to sections perhaps. That way, students may feel less discouraged from the high amount of readings and will focus better on what they know is crucial to understanding the materials.
The questions involving math were sometimes difficult, though the discussion sections helped a lot. I'd say a review lecture before midterms would be helpful.
Yes, it gives you a good overview of natural disasters and how they work.
Yes, especially if you're a non-STEM major looking for a decently interesting science credit. Not a complete gut, but you won't lose sleep over it, either.
If you want a relatively easy science credit, why not.
It's a relatively easy science. take it seriously from day 1 and it's not bad
Yes, except be prepared to do a lot of math along with qualitative work
yes, good science class for non science majors that is interesting yet challenging.
It's a good science for non-science majors, if you are willing to put in the work to go to section for the psets every week and study for the midterms.
This is not a gut science. That's basically all you need to know. Take it if you want intro GG basically.
yes, good gut
yes best science credit ever
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student in need of a science credit because it is not extremely difficult and the work load is manageable.

Take this class! You will learn a lot about the world. It is very accessible to people who don't have a strong science background, but it is still challenging at times. This means the course actually teaches you things though, and it is easy to stay engaged. If you are having trouble with the problem sets, attending section or reaching out for help can really change things around. The course is very doable, even if a bit challenging.

Natural Disasters was overall a great course that I feel I learned something valuable in. Great science for non-science majors, but be prepared to do more work than you think you have to. None of it is particularly hard (they basically walk you through the entire problem set in section), but you really have to study and understand the concepts for the midterms/final. None of the concepts are that hard to grasp, but you just have to put in the work to understand them.

Yes 100%, 11/10 would recommend. Professor Bercovici and Long are amazing! They both are very knowledgeable and keep the class interesting. Also, there is option section each week where you go and they pretty much do the pset for you, its great! As someone who went to lecture everyday, I barely had to study for the tests as they were big picture and did very well on them.
I would recommend this course to a student who is not particularly a science of STEM person but still needs to fulfill a science credit. You will learn a lot and it is relevant to our world today.

Pros: Lots of Resources available (Office hours, peer tutoring, voluntary sections) to help you if you need it. Voluntary sections three times a week that will run through HW problems. Not a whole lot of work, and no one thing weighs too heavily on your grade. You could also go on a field trip to some exotic locale during spring break (Seriously, Not joking!)

Cons: Meets 3 times a week (MWF). Lectures can be really boring and dry. Tests are all about memorizing what was in lectures. No reason to really want to go to class everyday.

Overall, this is an alright course and a not-too-painful science credit if you need one, though there are certainly easier/more interesting ones out there. Not too hard, and pretty routine: put the work in and study, and you will do well.
Yes! It's more work than one might expect, but the material is so interesting and well-taught.
Excellent science credit for non-majors.

Yesbut hesitantly. This is not a real gut. The first midterm is harder than you might think (know what a seismic gap is). Go to lecture. Go to section to do the psets. It's an interesting coursebut it's more work than you may have originally expected.
Yes! This course was so fun and it left you feeling as though you now know more than you did. It covered so many interesting things that you can't learn in any other class.

Yes, But it isn't a "Gut." The sections will help a lot when it comes to understanding the homework, and studying for exams, but the homework is not easy, and It takes several hours to complete, even working in groups.

Take it for the sweet, sweet QR credit, the potential to go on the tropical geology field trip, and remember that this class is not a gut! Perhaps it was in past years, but this is NOT THE CASE. Attend class, take notes, and go to section. It will all be okay. (Section is the KEY to doing well on the problem sets.)

The course is very straightforward for the most part. Until the last few lectures, that feel like fillers, it is easy to tell what topics will be asked of you on the exams. The psets are the only drawback of the course, and they aren't fun. They're doable, but they take up hours, which non-STEM folks taking the class will find challenging. The sections are a tremendous help though, attacking the psets without any guidance would be a big challenge. 
Overall: If you're looking to knock out a science credit and willing to put in the time of attending sections and doing the psets this is a good class to take. Topics are actually interesting for most lectures.
Ideal class to get a science credit for people that don't want to take intro biology or chemistry.
Take this course if you are looking for a science credit that is more quantitative. Problem sets are manageable as are the midterms and final.

Definitely take this class if the material sounds interesting to you. There are lots of people who take it as an easy science credit but if you want to be engaged with the material, there are plenty of opportunities to do that.
Yes! It's unacceptable not to be aware of how the world works around you. The professors are great, really care, and deliver the material in the best way possible.

I would recommend this course to any other student that is not a science major. The material is not too complicated and is very interesting. Who would not want to learn about the Earth's natural disasters?

This is a great class for someone who needs a science credit. This is also a good class for someone interested in the material as a science major, as long as they are not frustrated by the time taken for very basic physics.
If you need a science credit and are comfortable with math below calculus, take this. If you like rocks or are how natural phenomena occur, take this course.
be prepared to solve physics problems in a class that doesnt prepare you for that material and only glosses over natural disasters in themselves. poorly run and not interesting.
Yes. This is a good course for non science majors
Sure, its a good science credit, straightforward

Natty D's is a great science course to take if you are not a STEM Major. Don't be fooled; it is NOT a gut. That being said, the professors are great and the course material is super interesting if you actually involve yourself in the course. I definitely recommend it. And if you put in work into the course, it is definitely not hard to get an A/A-.
This is a good science credit, and it is interesting and relevant to current events.

I loved this class so much-I wrote two really really long answers to the other questions, so if you want to know more and why, read that too. I would absolutely recommend. I've only taken four classes at Yale so far, and this has been my absolute favorite.

I would highly recommend this course to another student, especially one curious about the basics of the solar system, and earth's weather. This course is incredibly interesting, with subject matter that I know I wouldn't have learned anywhere else. The lectures are super entertaining and raise questions about human existence and our relationship to the environment. Already I have found this course incredibly useful in understanding everything from politics to weather. In taking this course, keep in mind that it is a lot more work than you'll expect. The psets do take time, and the exams are hard in that they cover a lot of content in a very short period of time.

NatD is a pretty easy science class. The math is tedious mostly algebra and unit conversion, think non-calculus high school physics, but if you'd rather have that than more conceptually challenging math then NatD will be fine. The concepts covered in the class are actually pretty interesting, but you have to go out of your way to understand them in greater depth. A solid gut, overall.
I would definitely recommend this course to another Yale student. The professors are highly engaged and knowledgeable and are very accessible with their office hours.
Yes I would recommend this course. It is very informative on topics that occur in our everyday lives and very interesting. The professors are very nice and willing to help whenever you need it.

Take Natty D! I feel like I have a much deeper understanding about the earth and climate. The class isn't too difficult if you pay attention in lecture and take it seriously. The professors are both really cool and experts in their fields. This entire class was an awesome experience and it is very accessible for non-science majors.
Never

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I came in knowing very little about natural disasters, and left the class understanding how and why they occur, as well as gaining some insight into disasters in recent history. The workload was not too difficult (one pset per week, 2 midterms, and a final), and there was a lot of support from the teaching staff when I had any confusions. Very interesting and fun class!

I would definitely recommend, especially to a non-STEM major who is looking to practice the basics of math, physics and even a little bit of chemistry without taking a course with a lot of pre-meds and pre-engineers. I was able to practice skills I'd forgotten from high school and learned a ton about natural disasters which was really interesting and frankly very relevant!
Yes. Not necessarily a gut. Go to homework sections and study those for the test

DEFINITELY recommend. However, be warned, it has a gut name but it is not a gut. You actually learn pretty cool stuff, but if you don't study/go over lecture notes, you'll be in trouble. It's a fun class though.
absolutely
Yes - good science credit for non-science major
No. Never. You are better off just googling natural disasters and reading the wikipedia page. May be the worst class I have taken at Yale

Yes! I definitely recommend. It is a pretty cool class- I learned a lot of fun random facts as well as a basic understanding of how the earth functions. It is a great science credit for non science majors.

If you are looking to gain a broad overview of earth science, this is a great course. You learn about a lot of interesting things, from earthquakes to the origin of life. You don't need great quantitative skills because they will help you do the whole problem set in section, and there aren't many quantitative questions on the tests. So as long as you go to lecture and have a good understanding of the concepts it won't be too difficult and you can learn a lot of very interesting, relevant things.

I would! I think it was a relevant course to what was going on in the actual world and what will be going on. The physics and math parts of the course was definitely manageable and interesting. This was a great introduction overall to the geology field.
I would. It was very interesting and didn't require a ton of work.
